Rybak of Minneapolis, MN; former Vice President Walter F. Mondale; and St. Anthony, MN, resident Rebekah Erler, her husband Ben Erler, and their sons Jack and Henry. He also referred to his sister Maya Soetoro-Ng. Audio was not available for verification of the content of these remarks.

titleInfo.title: The President's Weekly Address

extension.notes: Note: The address was recorded at approximately 4:25 p.m. on June 27 in the Blue Room at the White House for broadcast on June 28. In the address, the President referred to St. Anthony, MN, resident Rebekah Erler, her husband Ben Erler, and their sons Jack and Henry. The transcript was made available by the Office of the Press Secretary on June 27, but was embargoed for release until 6 a.m. on June 28.

titleInfo.title: Remarks at a Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Pride Month Reception

extension.searchTitle: PPP 2014, Book1, Public Papers of the Presidents of the United States: Barack Obama (2014, Book I); Remarks at a Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Pride Month Reception
extension.notes: Note: The President spoke at 5:40 p.m. in the East Room at the White House. In his remarks, he referred to Chicago, IL, residents Darby Patrick and Jim Bova; Todd M. Hughes, U.S. Circuit Court Judge for the Federal Circuit; Judith E. Levy, U.S. District Court Judge for the Eastern District of Michigan; Nitza I. Quiones Alejandro, U.S. District Court Judge for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania; Deborah A. Batts, U.S. District Court Judge for the Southern District of New York; Tobias B. Wolff, professor of law, University of Pennsylvania Law School; Lawrence Goldyn, medical director, Mendocino Coast Clinics in Fort Bragg, CA; Charlie J. Fabella, Jr., husband of White House Executive Pastry Chef William Yosses; Michael Sam, defensive end, National Football League's St. Louis Rams; actor Laverne Cox; Edith Windsor, plaintiff in the U.S. Supreme Court case United States v. Windsor; and Roberta A. Kaplan, partner, Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP, who argued before the U.S. Supreme Court on behalf of Ms. Windsor.

titleInfo.title: Statement on the Deaths of Eyal Yifrach, Gilad Shaar, and Naftali Fraenkel of Israel

extension.searchTitle: PPP 2014, Book1, Public Papers of the Presidents of the United States: Barack Obama (2014, Book I); Statement on the Deaths of Eyal Yifrach, Gilad Shaar, and Naftali Fraenkel of Israel
extension.notes: Note: The statement referred to Ori and Iris Yifrach, parents of Eyal Yifrach; Bat Galim Shaar and Ofir Shaar, parents of Gilad Shaar; and Avi and Rachel Fraenkel, parents of Naftali Fraenkel. All three boys were abducted while hitchhiking in the West Bank on June 12. Their bodies were recovered by Israeli authorities on June 30.
